chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected insomnia?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Take a history and ask about:

  • Symptoms such as difficulty in getting to sleep, difficulty maintaining sleep, early wakening, non-restorative sleep and daytime impairment.
  • Duration and frequency of symptoms.
    • Unsatisfactory sleep without reported functional impairment does not meet the diagnostic criteria for insomnia — ask about beliefs on normal sleep.
    • For more information, see the section on Normal sleep patterns.
  • Sleep schedule including bedtimes, time taken to get to sleep, awakenings, and rise time.
  • Sleep environment.
  • Possible triggers such as stress, shift work and jet lag.
  • Behaviours during sleep such as snoring, witnessed apnoea, restless legs, or sleep walking which may indicate an alternative cause. 
    • A collateral history from a partner/family member can be helpful.
    • For more information see the CKS topics on Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome and Sleep disorders - shift work and jet lag. 
  • Past medical history including:
    • Previous sleep problems and treatment.
    • Comorbidities such as chronic pain, medical disorders (such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart failure or gastro-oesophageal reflux disease) and psychological disorders (such as stress, anxiety, or depression).
  • Impact of insomnia on quality of life, ability to drive, employment, relationships, and mood.
  • Medications and substance use including caffeine, alcohol, nicotine and illicit drugs.

Carry out an examination where appropriate:

  • Depending on the specific clinical situation examination may help identify comorbid conditions.

Consider the need for investigations:

  • A sleep diary can help assess sleep difficulties and daytime impairment over time; it should be kept for 2 weeks and record:
    • The time of going to bed and getting up.
    • The time taken to get to sleep and the number and duration of episodes of waking through the night.
    • Episodes of daytime tiredness and naps.
    • Times of meals, alcohol consumption, caffeine consumption, and significant events during the day, such as exercise or stress.
    • Rating of sleep quality (ask the person to rate the quality of their sleep each night, from 1 to 5, where 1 is very poor and 5 is very good).
  • An example of a 2-week sleep diary is available from the American Academy of Sleep Medicine.
  • Depending on the clinical situation, other investigations may be appropriate for example where a comorbid condition (such as hyperthyroidism, respiratory or cardiovascular disease) is suspected.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Normal sleep patterns
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Sleep is an important factor in many processes including neural development, learning, memory, regulation of emotion, and cardiovascular and metabolic functioning.
  • There is no standard definition of normal sleep — the amount of sleep needed to ensure good health varies from person to person and with ageing.
    • With ageing the number of awakenings increases and total sleep time decreases.
  • The American Thoracic Society suggests that the optimal sleep duration in adults is 7–9 hours:
    • Short sleep duration (6 hours or less per 24 hours) is associated with adverse outcomes including mortality.
    • Long sleep duration (more than 9–10 hours per 24 hours) may be normal but has also been associated with adverse outcomes — however, long sleep duration may be a marker of ill-health and physical inactivity rather than a cause of ill-health.
  • The normal time taken to fall asleep (sleep-onset latency) is usually considered to be less than 30 minutes.

[Morin, 2015; Mukherjee, 2015; Wilson, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to assess a person with suspected insomnia are based on the clinical guidelines Assessment to management of adult insomnia [Alberta Medical Association, 2015], and European guideline for the diagnosis and treatment of insomnia [Riemann, 2017], the American Thoracic Society Statement The importance of healthy sleep. Recommendations and future priorities [Mukherjee, 2015], the Australasian Sleep Association position statement on The use of psychological/behavioral treatments in the management of insomnia in adults [Ree, 2017], the British Association for Psychopharmacology consensus statement Evidence-based treatment of insomnia, parasomnias and circadian rhythm disorders: an update [Wilson, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Maness, 2015; Morin, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2019; Grima, 2019]. 

Insomnia symptoms

  • To fulfil the diagnostic criteria for insomnia, sleep difficulties must have a significant impact on daytime functioning [Sateia, 2014; Wilson, 2019; WHO, 2019]. 

Consider other sleep disorders

  • Sleep disturbance and daytime fatigue can be caused by several sleep disorders including sleep apnoea and parasomnias — referral to secondary care for further assessment may be indicated [Morin, 2015; Grima, 2019; Wilson, 2019]. 

Comorbidities

  • Insomnia can co-exist with many other medical and psychological conditions, often with bidirectional or interactive effects.
    • Recognition and optimal management of all conditions is needed to achieve a successful long-term outcome [Sateia, 2014; Alberta Medical Association, 2015; Ree, 2017; Wilson, 2019]. 
  • Comorbid psychiatric conditions (such as depression, anxiety disorders and substance abuse) should always be considered in a person presenting with insomnia [Alberta Medical Association, 2015; Wilson, 2019]. 

Medications and substance use

  • Many prescription and over the counter drugs (such as corticosteroids, theophylline, salbutamol, terbutaline, pseudoephedrine, phenylephrine, phenylpropanolamine, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) can interfere with sleep and may lead to insomnia [Cunnington, 2016; BMJ Best Practice, 2019]. 
  • Alcohol is a common maladaptive self-treatment strategy in insomnia and can contribute to sleep-maintenance difﬁculties [Riemann, 2017]. 

Sleep diary

  • Several guidelines and review articles recommend the use of a sleep diary to help assess sleep patterns, lifestyle and the impact of sleep disturbance on daytime functioning. They may also be useful in monitoring effects of treatment and give the person a broader perspective on their sleep issues [Alberta Medical Association, 2015; Morin, 2015; Ree, 2017; Riemann, 2017; Grima, 2019; Wilson, 2019]. 

Normal sleep patterns

  • There is no standard definition of what constitutes normal sleep. Insomnia is highly subjective and although most healthy adults typically sleep between 7 and 9 hours per night, patterns vary greatly between people [NICE, 2004]. 
  • The information on normal sleeping patterns is taken from the American Thoracic Society Statement: The importance of healthy sleep. Recommendations and future priorities [Mukherjee, 2015], the British Association for Psychopharmacology consensus statement Evidence-based treatment of insomnia, parasomnias and circadian rhythm disorders: an update [Wilson, 2019], and expert opinion in a review article [Morin, 2015].
